channel.title: Science & Engineering Extracurricular Award - Introduction to R on Miscellaneous R stuff
channel.description: Recent content in Science & Engineering Extracurricular Award - Introduction to R on Miscellaneous R stuff

item.title: 1. Getting started with R
item.description: R as a calculator Get the worksheet here: worksheet 1 1 + 1 10 - 5 10 / 2 2^3 # 2 to the power of 3 2 * 5 # with or without spaces - doesn't make a difference 2*5 Using spaces and lines between your code can make it easier to read. Don’t forget to make lots of comments with # How to find help In R, use ?

item.title: 2. Vectors, variables and other objects
item.description: Vectors, variables and other objects Get the worksheet here worksheet 2 What is a vector? It’s an ordered collection of data. For example, it could be a single column of a table [1] 3.79 63.00 0.53 6.46 11.46 0.29 0.08 0.74 Or a single value [1] 3.141593 Types of vector Numeric continuous integer Character (string) text Logical TRUE or FALSE Vector with a single numeric item a <- 1 b <- 5 x <- 100 # note the assign operator: <- # this means assign value on the right hand side to the variable/object name on the left a ## [1] 1 x ## [1] 100 Naming objects… - Don’t use reserved words: ?

item.title: 2. Vectors, variables and other objects
item.description: The <> a ‘table’ in R Get the worksheet here worksheet 3 We can think of a data frame as a collection of vectors of the same length. For example, let’s combine two vectors into a data frame # Think back to this vector: v1 ## [1] 50 20 3 15 43 HOw long is it? i.e. how many elements does it have? length(v1) ## [1] 5 What type (numeric, character) are the elements?
